 I'm very familiar with ammonium nitrate. Many of my fellow rocket hobbyists use it in their propellant. Ammonium nitrate is classified as an explosive, but under "normal" conditions, it is relatively stable. To make solid rocket propellant, the prills or granules are ground finer. The finer the powder, the more reactive it is. Ammonium nitrate melts at a low temperature and easily forms pools of liquid in a fire. If it is confined, it will detonate as it did in Texas City, without a fuel source present. In bagged prill form it should be very safe to handle and NOT a static detonation risk unless a fine dust is present in enclosed tank cars. Under those conditions, even grain is an explosion risk.
 That being said, I don't believe N. Korea for a second. I think a munitions or rocket fuel train coming from China blew up.
